awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I: Transfer Training Device to Reduce Falls and Increase Mobility in Older Adults
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is a novel walker with active corrective feedback and training protocols enabling patients the ability to reliably and repeatedly transition from a seated position to a standing posture. Falls among elderly adults are the leading cause of injury resulting in 3 million emergency room visits and 800,000 hospitalizations.  These accidents account for $50 billion in direct medical costs each year. This project aims to develop a novel device which directly improves the sit-to-stand (STS) transfer phase which accounts for 41% of falls in elderly and/or cognitively impaired adults. Over half of individuals using walkers currently do not receive the proper assistive-device utilization training due to varying therapist techniques, communication, environment, or the patient's cognitive abilities.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project aims to develop a device for ensuring a safer and more consistent transition from a sit-to-stand posture in patients using front-wheel walkers. Current sit-to-stand training relies solely upon verbal therapist instruction or demonstration and often results in lack of consistency in delivery. The proposed device integrates biomechanical measurements, trained therapist observations, and patient auditory and visual feedback, in conjunction with an educational and training protocol, to ensure proper patient biomechanics, in a semi-autonomous manner.  A prototype system will be developed and validated in a patient proof of concept study demonstrating consistent and reliable posture changes in order to significantly reduce the risks for falls and injuries, while reducing emotional and physical demands on patients and caregivers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report: STTR Phase I - Transfer Training Device to Reduce Falls and Increase Mobility in Older Adults

Federal Award ID: 2223163 Report Submission Period: 07/15/2023 to 06/30/2024
Falls remain one of the most significant health risks for older adults, often resulting in serious injury and loss of independence. The aim of this STTR Phase I project was to develop and test a Transfer Training Device (TTD) that addresses improper use of assistive devices, specifically during Sit-to-Stand (STS) transfers, which is a critical activity in daily mobility. Our device seeks to reduce fall risks by providing real-time feedback to users, helping them correct unsafe movements and improve their use of Front-Wheel Walkers (FWWs).

  • Intellectual Merit:The intellectual merit of our work lies in its novel approach to addressing fall prevention through real-time feedback technology. By integrating a system that provides real-time feedback during STS transitions, the Transfer Training Device assists older adults in performing these movements more safely. Previous methods to mitigate fall risk rely heavily on training by healthcare professionals, often leaving gaps in patient performance when unsupervised. This device extends the learning process beyond clinical settings, allowing older adults to self-correct and adapt their movements in real-time.

Throughout the life of this award, we successfully developed a working prototype of the TTD. The device has shown promise in improving users' posture, reducing forward leaning, and promoting slower, more controlled movements—key factors in preventing falls. Our early-stage testing with older adults has demonstrated that the system can make a tangible difference in how patients interact with their FWWs during high-risk transitions, such as from sitting to standing.

  • Broader Impacts: The broader impact of this project extends to the growing aging population in the U.S. and around the world. As older adults increasingly rely on Assistive Devices to maintain their independence, ensuring the proper and safe use of these devices is critical. By focusing on real-time feedback, the TTD addresses a fundamental gap in current fall prevention methods: the lack of continuous, user-centered guidance.

This project also provided valuable training opportunities for students and researchers. Collaborations between the University, healthcare providers, and the company fostered an environment of innovation, resulting in practical solutions with the potential for commercialization. In addition, the engagement with the NSF I-Corps program helped to gain deeper insights into the needs of end-users and refined the approach to market entry, ensuring that the device will meet real-world demands.

Addressing the Impact of Decreased Healthcare Workers: As healthcare facilities face increasing workforce shortages, particularly in long-term care and rehabilitation settings, devices like the TTD can play a critical role in supporting both patients and staff. With fewer healthcare workers available to provide one-on-one assistance, the TTD offers an opportunity to supplement care by providing patients with real-time feedback when therapists or aides are unavailable.
By promoting safer, more controlled movements during Sit-to-Stand Transfers, the device helps patients gain confidence in their mobility and reduces their reliance on healthcare staff for constant supervision. This not only improves patient safety but also allows healthcare workers to allocate their time more effectively, focusing on patients with more complex needs. In this way, the TTD serves as an important tool in addressing gaps in care caused by staffing shortages, improving patient outcomes while alleviating some of the pressures on an overburdened healthcare system.

Summary of Outcomes:

  • Development of a Prototype: Engineered a functional prototype of the TTD, which includes a real-time feedback system to guide users during Sit-to-Stand transitions. The device has been tested in a controlled environment and meets all initial safety and usability benchmarks.
  • Positive Initial Testing Results: Early testing has shown that the feedback system encourages users to move more deliberately, improves postural alignment, and reduces risky behaviors, such as leaning too far forward or engaging the walker too early in the transfer process.
  • User-Centered Design and Focus Group Feedback: Feedback from healthcare professionals, caregivers, and older adults has been instrumental in refining both the device and the accompanying training protocol. Focus groups have validated the practical application of the TTD and highlighted its potential to reduce falls in real-world settings.

Future Directions: This project has laid the groundwork for future studies and clinical trials that will assess the long-term effectiveness of the TTD in reducing falls and enhancing mobility among older adults. Our work also opens the door for broader applications of real-time feedback technologies in other areas of physical rehabilitation.

  • The outcomes of this award represent a significant step forward in Assistive Device safety and fall prevention, with the potential to enhance the quality of life for older adults and reduce healthcare costs associated with falls.
  • The project outcomes report highlights the innovation and public health importance of our work in reducing falls among older adults using Assistive Devices and a commitment to advancing Assistive Device Technology.
